nsVrOspf.name: nsVrOspf
nsVrOspf.contactinfo: Customer Support 1194 North Mathilda Avenue Sunnyvale, California 94089-1206 USA Tel: 1-800-638-8296 E-mail: customerservice@juniper.net HTTP://www.juniper.net
nsVrOspf.description: The MIB module to describe the NS-OSPF Version 2 Protocol

Status.name: Status
Status.description: The status of an interface: 'enabled' indicates that it is willing to communicate with other OSPF Routers, while 'disabled' indicates that it is not.

PositiveInteger.name: PositiveInteger
PositiveInteger.description: A positive integer. Values in excess are precluded as unnecessary and prone to interoperability issues.

HelloRange.name: HelloRange
HelloRange.description: The range of intervals on which hello messages are exchanged.

UpToMaxAge.name: UpToMaxAge
UpToMaxAge.description: The values that one might find or configure for variables bounded by the maximum age of an LSA.

DesignatedRouterPriority.name: DesignatedRouterPriority
DesignatedRouterPriority.description: The values defined for the priority of a system for becoming the designated router.

TOSType.name: TOSType
TOSType.description: Type of Service is defined as a mapping to the IP Type of Service Flags as defined in the IP Forwarding Table MIB +-----+-----+-----+-----+-----+-----+-----+-----+ | | | | | PRECEDENCE | TYPE OF SERVICE | 0 | | | | | +-----+-----+-----+-----+-----+-----+-----+-----+ IP TOS IP TOS Field Policy Field Policy Contents Code Contents Code 0 0 0 0 ==> 0 0 0 0 1 ==> 2 0 0 1 0 ==> 4 0 0 1 1 ==> 6 0 1 0 0 ==> 8 0 1 0 1 ==> 10 0 1 1 0 ==> 12 0 1 1 1 ==> 14 1 0 0 0 ==> 16 1 0 0 1 ==> 18 1 0 1 0 ==> 20 1 0 1 1 ==> 22 1 1 0 0 ==> 24 1 1 0 1 ==> 26 1 1 1 0 ==> 28 1 1 1 1 ==> 30 The remaining values are left for future definition.

nsVrOspfGeneralTable.name: nsVrOspfGeneralTable
nsVrOspfGeneralTable.description: Ospf general information table per VR

nsVrOspfGeneralEntry.name: nsVrOspfGeneralEntry
nsVrOspfGeneralEntry.description: Ospf general information table per VR

nsVrOspfRouterId.name: nsVrOspfRouterId
nsVrOspfRouterId.description: A 32-bit integer uniquely identifying the router in the Autonomous System. By convention, to ensure uniqueness, this should default to the value of one of the router's IP interface addresses.

nsVrOspfAdminStat.name: nsVrOspfAdminStat
nsVrOspfAdminStat.description: The administrative status of OSPF in the router. The value 'enabled' denotes that the OSPF Process is active on at least one inter- face; 'disabled' disables it on all inter- faces.

nsVrOspfVersionNumber.name: nsVrOspfVersionNumber
nsVrOspfVersionNumber.description: The current version number of the OSPF proto- col is 2.

nsVrOspfAreaBdrRtrStatus.name: nsVrOspfAreaBdrRtrStatus
nsVrOspfAreaBdrRtrStatus.reference: OSPF Version 2, Section 3 Splitting the AS into Areas
nsVrOspfAreaBdrRtrStatus.description: A flag to note whether this router is an area border router.

nsVrOspfASBdrRtrStatus.name: nsVrOspfASBdrRtrStatus
nsVrOspfASBdrRtrStatus.reference: OSPF Version 2, Section 3.3 Classification of routers
nsVrOspfASBdrRtrStatus.description: A flag to note whether this router is config- ured as an Autonomous System border router.

nsVrOspfExternLsaCount.name: nsVrOspfExternLsaCount
nsVrOspfExternLsaCount.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix A.4.5 AS external link advertisements
nsVrOspfExternLsaCount.description: The number of external (LS type 5) link-state advertisements in the link-state database.

nsVrOspfExternLsaCksumSum.name: nsVrOspfExternLsaCksumSum
nsVrOspfExternLsaCksumSum.description: The 32-bit unsigned sum of the LS checksums of the external link-state advertisements con- tained in the link-state database. This sum can be used to determine if there has been a change in a router's link state database, and to compare the link-state database of two routers.

nsVrOspfTOSSupport.name: nsVrOspfTOSSupport
nsVrOspfTOSSupport.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix F.1.2 Optional TOS support
nsVrOspfTOSSupport.description: The router's support for type-of-service rout- ing.

nsVrOspfOriginateNewLsas.name: nsVrOspfOriginateNewLsas
nsVrOspfOriginateNewLsas.description: The number of new link-state advertisements that have been originated. This number is in- cremented each time the router originates a new LSA.

nsVrOspfRxNewLsas.name: nsVrOspfRxNewLsas
nsVrOspfRxNewLsas.description: The number of link-state advertisements re- ceived determined to be new instantiations. This number does not include newer instantia- tions of self-originated link-state advertise- ments.

nsVrOspfExtLsdbLimit.name: nsVrOspfExtLsdbLimit
nsVrOspfExtLsdbLimit.description: The maximum number of non-default AS- external-LSAs entries that can be stored in the link-state database. If the value is -1, then there is no limit. When the number of non-default AS-external-LSAs in a router's link-state database reaches nsVrOspfExtLsdbLimit, the router enters Overflow- State. The router never holds more than nsVrOspfExtLsdbLimit non-default AS-external-LSAs in its database. OspfExtLsdbLimit MUST be set identically in all routers attached to the OSPF backbone and/or any regular OSPF area. (i.e., OSPF stub areas and NSSAs are excluded).

nsVrOspfMulticastExtensions.name: nsVrOspfMulticastExtensions
nsVrOspfMulticastExtensions.description: A Bit Mask indicating whether the router is forwarding IP multicast (Class D) datagrams based on the algorithms defined in the Multi- cast Extensions to OSPF. Bit 0, if set, indicates that the router can forward IP multicast datagrams in the router's directly attached areas (called intra-area mul- ticast routing). Bit 1, if set, indicates that the router can forward IP multicast datagrams between OSPF areas (called inter-area multicast routing). Bit 2, if set, indicates that the router can forward IP multicast datagrams between Auto- nomous Systems (called inter-AS multicast rout- ing). Only certain combinations of bit settings are allowed, namely: 0 (no multicast forwarding is enabled), 1 (intra-area multicasting only), 3 (intra-area and inter-area multicasting), 5 (intra-area and inter-AS multicasting) and 7 (multicasting everywhere). By default, no mul- ticast forwarding is enabled.

nsVrOspfExitOverflowInterval.name: nsVrOspfExitOverflowInterval
nsVrOspfExitOverflowInterval.description: The number of seconds that, after entering OverflowState, a router will attempt to leave OverflowState. This allows the router to again originate non-default AS-external-LSAs. When set to 0, the router will not leave Overflow- State until restarted.

nsVrOspfDemandExtensions.name: nsVrOspfDemandExtensions
nsVrOspfDemandExtensions.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix on Demand Routing
nsVrOspfDemandExtensions.description: The router's support for demand routing.

nsVrOspfGeneralVRID.name: nsVrOspfGeneralVRID
nsVrOspfGeneralVRID.description: Virtual Router ID. VRID range for system created VRs: [1-1024] and for user created VRs: [1025-2048]

nsVrOspfAreaTable.name: nsVrOspfAreaTable
nsVrOspfAreaTable.reference: OSPF Version 2, Section 6 The Area Data Struc- ture
nsVrOspfAreaTable.description: Information describing the configured parame- ters and cumulative statistics of the router's attached areas.

nsVrOspfAreaEntry.name: nsVrOspfAreaEntry
nsVrOspfAreaEntry.description: Information describing the configured parame- ters and cumulative statistics of one of the router's attached areas.

nsVrOspfAreaId.name: nsVrOspfAreaId
nsVrOspfAreaId.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.2 Area parameters
nsVrOspfAreaId.description: A 32-bit integer uniquely identifying an area. Area ID 0.0.0.0 is used for the OSPF backbone.

nsVrOspfImportAsExtern.name: nsVrOspfImportAsExtern
nsVrOspfImportAsExtern.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.2 Area parameters
nsVrOspfImportAsExtern.description: The area's support for importing AS external link- state advertisements.

nsVrOspfSpfRuns.name: nsVrOspfSpfRuns
nsVrOspfSpfRuns.description: The number of times that the intra-area route table has been calculated using this area's link-state database. This is typically done using Dijkstra's algorithm.

nsVrOspfAreaBdrRtrCount.name: nsVrOspfAreaBdrRtrCount
nsVrOspfAreaBdrRtrCount.description: The total number of area border routers reach- able within this area. This is initially zero, and is calculated in each SPF Pass.

nsVrOspfAsBdrRtrCount.name: nsVrOspfAsBdrRtrCount
nsVrOspfAsBdrRtrCount.description: The total number of Autonomous System border routers reachable within this area. This is initially zero, and is calculated in each SPF Pass.

nsVrOspfAreaLsaCount.name: nsVrOspfAreaLsaCount
nsVrOspfAreaLsaCount.description: The total number of link-state advertisements in this area's link-state database, excluding AS External LSA's.

nsVrOspfAreaLsaCksumSum.name: nsVrOspfAreaLsaCksumSum
nsVrOspfAreaLsaCksumSum.description: The 32-bit unsigned sum of the link-state ad- vertisements' LS checksums contained in this area's link-state database. This sum excludes external (LS type 5) link-state advertisements. The sum can be used to determine if there has been a change in a router's link state data- base, and to compare the link-state database of two routers.

nsVrOspfAreaSummary.name: nsVrOspfAreaSummary
nsVrOspfAreaSummary.description: The variable nsVrOspfAreaSummary controls the im- port of summary LSAs into stub areas. It has no effect on other areas. If it is noAreaSummary, the router will neither originate nor propagate summary LSAs into the stub area. It will rely entirely on its de- fault route. If it is sendAreaSummary, the router will both summarize and propagate summary LSAs.

nsVrOspfAreaStatus.name: nsVrOspfAreaStatus
nsVrOspfAreaStatus.description: This variable displays the status of the en- try. Setting it to 'invalid' has the effect of rendering it inoperative. The internal effect (row removal) is implementation dependent.

nsVrOspfAreaVRID.name: nsVrOspfAreaVRID
nsVrOspfAreaVRID.description: Virtual Router ID. VRID range for system created VRs: [1-1024] and for user created VRs: [1025-2048]

nsVrOspfStubAreaTable.name: nsVrOspfStubAreaTable
nsVrOspfStubAreaTable.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.2, Area Parameters
nsVrOspfStubAreaTable.description: The set of metrics that will be advertised by a default Area Border Router into a stub area.

nsVrOspfStubAreaEntry.name: nsVrOspfStubAreaEntry
nsVrOspfStubAreaEntry.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.2, Area Parameters
nsVrOspfStubAreaEntry.description: The metric for a given Type of Service that will be advertised by a default Area Border Router into a stub area.

nsVrOspfStubAreaId.name: nsVrOspfStubAreaId
nsVrOspfStubAreaId.description: The 32 bit identifier for the Stub Area. On creation, this can be derived from the in- stance.

nsVrOspfStubTOS.name: nsVrOspfStubTOS
nsVrOspfStubTOS.description: The Type of Service associated with the metric. On creation, this can be derived from the instance.

nsVrOspfStubMetric.name: nsVrOspfStubMetric
nsVrOspfStubMetric.description: The metric value applied at the indicated type of service. By default, this equals the least metric at the type of service among the inter- faces to other areas.

nsVrOspfStubStatus.name: nsVrOspfStubStatus
nsVrOspfStubStatus.description: This variable displays the status of the en- try. Setting it to 'invalid' has the effect of rendering it inoperative. The internal effect (row removal) is implementation dependent.

nsVrOspfStubMetricType.name: nsVrOspfStubMetricType
nsVrOspfStubMetricType.description: This variable displays the type of metric ad- vertised as a default route.

nsVrOspfStubVRID.name: nsVrOspfStubVRID
nsVrOspfStubVRID.description: Virtual Router ID. VRID range for system created VRs: [1-1024] and for user created VRs: [1025-2048]

nsVrOspfLsdbTable.name: nsVrOspfLsdbTable
nsVrOspfLsdbTable.reference: OSPF Version 2, Section 12 Link State Adver- tisements
nsVrOspfLsdbTable.description: The OSPF Process's Link State Database.

nsVrOspfLsdbAreaId.name: nsVrOspfLsdbAreaId
nsVrOspfLsdbAreaId.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.2 Area parameters
nsVrOspfLsdbAreaId.description: The 32 bit identifier of the Area from which the LSA was received.

nsVrOspfLsdbType.name: nsVrOspfLsdbType
nsVrOspfLsdbType.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix A.4.1 The Link State Advertisement header
nsVrOspfLsdbType.description: The type of the link state advertisement. Each link state type has a separate advertise- ment format.

nsVrOspfLsdbLsid.name: nsVrOspfLsdbLsid
nsVrOspfLsdbLsid.reference: OSPF Version 2, Section 12.1.4 Link State ID
nsVrOspfLsdbLsid.description: The Link State ID is an LS Type Specific field containing either a Router ID or an IP Address; it identifies the piece of the routing domain that is being described by the advertisement.

nsVrOspfLsdbRouterId.name: nsVrOspfLsdbRouterId
nsVrOspfLsdbRouterId.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.1 Global parameters
nsVrOspfLsdbRouterId.description: The 32 bit number that uniquely identifies the originating router in the Autonomous System.

nsVrOspfLsdbSequence.name: nsVrOspfLsdbSequence
nsVrOspfLsdbSequence.reference: OSPF Version 2, Section 12.1.6 LS sequence number
nsVrOspfLsdbSequence.description: The sequence number field is a signed 32-bit integer. It is used to detect old and dupli- cate link state advertisements. The space of sequence numbers is linearly ordered. The larger the sequence number the more recent the advertisement.

nsVrOspfLsdbAge.name: nsVrOspfLsdbAge
nsVrOspfLsdbAge.description: This field is the age of the link state adver- tisement in seconds.

nsVrOspfLsdbChecksum.name: nsVrOspfLsdbChecksum
nsVrOspfLsdbChecksum.description: This field is the checksum of the complete contents of the advertisement, excepting the age field. The age field is excepted so that an advertisement's age can be incremented without updating the checksum. The checksum used is the same that is used for ISO connec- tionless datagrams; it is commonly referred to as the Fletcher checksum.

nsVrOspfLsdbAdvertisement.name: nsVrOspfLsdbAdvertisement
nsVrOspfLsdbAdvertisement.reference: OSPF Version 2, Section 12 Link State Adver- tisements
nsVrOspfLsdbAdvertisement.description: The entire Link State Advertisement, including its header.

nsVrOspfLsdbVRID.name: nsVrOspfLsdbVRID
nsVrOspfLsdbVRID.description: Virtual Router ID. VRID range for system created VRs: [1-1024] and for user created VRs: [1025-2048]

nsVrOspfHostTable.name: nsVrOspfHostTable
nsVrOspfHostTable.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.6 Host route param- eters
nsVrOspfHostTable.description: The list of Hosts, and their metrics, that the router will advertise as host routes.

nsVrOspfHostEntry.name: nsVrOspfHostEntry
nsVrOspfHostEntry.description: A metric to be advertised, for a given type of service, when a given host is reachable.

nsVrOspfHostIpAddress.name: nsVrOspfHostIpAddress
nsVrOspfHostIpAddress.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.6 Host route parame- ters
nsVrOspfHostIpAddress.description: The IP Address of the Host.

nsVrOspfHostTOS.name: nsVrOspfHostTOS
nsVrOspfHostTOS.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.6 Host route parame- ters
nsVrOspfHostTOS.description: The Type of Service of the route being config- ured.

nsVrOspfHostMetric.name: nsVrOspfHostMetric
nsVrOspfHostMetric.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.6 Host route parame- ters

nsVrOspfHostStatus.name: nsVrOspfHostStatus
nsVrOspfHostStatus.description: This variable displays the status of the en- try. Setting it to 'invalid' has the effect of rendering it inoperative. The internal effect (row removal) is implementation dependent.

nsVrOspfHostAreaID.name: nsVrOspfHostAreaID
nsVrOspfHostAreaID.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.2 Area parameters
nsVrOspfHostAreaID.description: The Area the Host Entry is to be found within. By default, the area that a subsuming OSPF in- terface is in, or 0.0.0.0

nsVrOspfHostVRID.name: nsVrOspfHostVRID
nsVrOspfHostVRID.description: Virtual Router ID. VRID range for system created VRs: [1-1024] and for user created VRs: [1025-2048]

nsVrOspfIfTable.name: nsVrOspfIfTable
nsVrOspfIfTable.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.3 Router interface parameters
nsVrOspfIfTable.description: The OSPF Interface Table describes the inter- faces from the viewpoint of OSPF.

nsVrOspfIfEntry.name: nsVrOspfIfEntry
nsVrOspfIfEntry.description: The OSPF Interface Entry describes one inter- face from the viewpoint of OSPF.

nsVrOspfIfIpAddress.name: nsVrOspfIfIpAddress
nsVrOspfIfIpAddress.description: The IP address of this OSPF interface.

nsVrOspfAddressLessIf.name: nsVrOspfAddressLessIf
nsVrOspfAddressLessIf.description: For the purpose of easing the instancing of addressed and addressless interfaces; This variable takes the value 0 on interfaces with IP Addresses, and the corresponding value of ifIndex for interfaces having no IP Address.

nsVrOspfIfAreaId.name: nsVrOspfIfAreaId
nsVrOspfIfAreaId.description: A 32-bit integer uniquely identifying the area to which the interface connects. Area ID 0.0.0.0 is used for the OSPF backbone.

nsVrOspfIfType.name: nsVrOspfIfType
nsVrOspfIfType.description: The OSPF interface type. By way of a default, this field may be intuited from the corresponding value of ifType. Broad- cast LANs, such as Ethernet and IEEE 802.5, take the value 'broadcast', X.25 and similar technologies take the value 'nbma', and links that are definitively point to point take the value 'pointToPoint'.

nsVrOspfIfAdminStat.name: nsVrOspfIfAdminStat
nsVrOspfIfAdminStat.description: The OSPF interface's administrative status. The value formed on the interface, and the in- terface will be advertised as an internal route to some area. The value 'disabled' denotes that the interface is external to OSPF.

nsVrOspfIfRtrPriority.name: nsVrOspfIfRtrPriority
nsVrOspfIfRtrPriority.description: The priority of this interface. Used in multi-access networks, this field is used in the designated router election algorithm. The value 0 signifies that the router is not eligi- ble to become the designated router on this particular network. In the event of a tie in this value, routers will use their Router ID as a tie breaker.

nsVrOspfIfTransitDelay.name: nsVrOspfIfTransitDelay
nsVrOspfIfTransitDelay.description: The estimated number of seconds it takes to transmit a link state update packet over this interface.

nsVrOspfIfRetransInterval.name: nsVrOspfIfRetransInterval
nsVrOspfIfRetransInterval.description: The number of seconds between link-state ad- vertisement retransmissions, for adjacencies belonging to this interface. This value is also used when retransmitting database descrip- tion and link-state request packets.

nsVrOspfIfHelloInterval.name: nsVrOspfIfHelloInterval
nsVrOspfIfHelloInterval.description: The length of time, in seconds, between the Hello packets that the router sends on the in- terface. This value must be the same for all routers attached to a common network.

nsVrOspfIfRtrDeadInterval.name: nsVrOspfIfRtrDeadInterval
nsVrOspfIfRtrDeadInterval.description: The number of seconds that a router's Hello packets have not been seen before it's neigh- bors declare the router down. This should be some multiple of the Hello interval. This value must be the same for all routers attached to a common network.

nsVrOspfIfPollInterval.name: nsVrOspfIfPollInterval
nsVrOspfIfPollInterval.description: The larger time interval, in seconds, between the Hello packets sent to an inactive non- broadcast multi- access neighbor.

nsVrOspfIfDesignatedRouter.name: nsVrOspfIfDesignatedRouter
nsVrOspfIfDesignatedRouter.description: The IP Address of the Designated Router.

nsVrOspfIfBackupDesignatedRouter.name: nsVrOspfIfBackupDesignatedRouter
nsVrOspfIfBackupDesignatedRouter.description: The IP Address of the Backup Designated Router.

nsVrOspfIfEvents.name: nsVrOspfIfEvents
nsVrOspfIfEvents.description: The number of times this OSPF interface has changed its state, or an error has occurred.

nsVrOspfIfAuthKey.name: nsVrOspfIfAuthKey
nsVrOspfIfAuthKey.reference: OSPF Version 2, Section 9 The Interface Data Structure
nsVrOspfIfAuthKey.description: The Authentication Key. If the Area's Author- ization Type is simplePassword, and the key length is shorter than 8 octets, the agent will left adjust and zero fill to 8 octets. Note that unauthenticated interfaces need no authentication key, and simple password authen- tication cannot use a key of more than 8 oc- tets. Larger keys are useful only with authen- tication mechanisms not specified in this docu- ment. When read, nsVrOspfIfAuthKey always returns an Oc- tet String of length zero.

nsVrOspfIfStatus.name: nsVrOspfIfStatus
nsVrOspfIfStatus.description: This variable displays the status of the en- try. Setting it to 'invalid' has the effect of rendering it inoperative. The internal effect (row removal) is implementation dependent.

nsVrOspfIfMulticastForwarding.name: nsVrOspfIfMulticastForwarding
nsVrOspfIfMulticastForwarding.description: The way multicasts should forwarded on this interface; not forwarded, forwarded as data link multicasts, or forwarded as data link uni- casts. Data link multicasting is not meaning- ful on point to point and NBMA interfaces, and setting nsVrOspfMulticastForwarding to 0 effective- ly disables all multicast forwarding.

nsVrOspfIfDemand.name: nsVrOspfIfDemand
nsVrOspfIfDemand.description: Indicates whether Demand OSPF procedures (hel- lo supression to FULL neighbors and setting the DoNotAge flag on proogated LSAs) should be per- formed on this interface.

nsVrOspfIfAuthType.name: nsVrOspfIfAuthType
nsVrOspfIfAuthType.description: The authentication type specified for an in- terface. Additional authentication types may be assigned locally.

nsVrOspfIfVRID.name: nsVrOspfIfVRID
nsVrOspfIfVRID.description: Virtual Router ID. VRID range for system created VRs: [1-1024] and for user created VRs: [1025-2048]

nsVrOspfIfMetricTable.name: nsVrOspfIfMetricTable
nsVrOspfIfMetricTable.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.3 Router interface parameters
nsVrOspfIfMetricTable.description: The TOS metrics for a non-virtual interface identified by the interface index.

nsVrOspfIfMetricEntry.name: nsVrOspfIfMetricEntry
nsVrOspfIfMetricEntry.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.3 Router interface parameters
nsVrOspfIfMetricEntry.description: A particular TOS metric for a non-virtual in- terface identified by the interface index.

nsVrOspfIfMetricIpAddress.name: nsVrOspfIfMetricIpAddress
nsVrOspfIfMetricIpAddress.description: The IP address of this OSPF interface. On row creation, this can be derived from the in- stance.

nsVrOspfIfMetricAddressLessIf.name: nsVrOspfIfMetricAddressLessIf
nsVrOspfIfMetricAddressLessIf.description: For the purpose of easing the instancing of addressed and addressless interfaces; This variable takes the value 0 on interfaces with IP Addresses, and the value of ifIndex for in- terfaces having no IP Address. On row crea- tion, this can be derived from the instance.

nsVrOspfIfMetricTOS.name: nsVrOspfIfMetricTOS
nsVrOspfIfMetricTOS.description: The type of service metric being referenced. On row creation, this can be derived from the instance.

nsVrOspfIfMetricValue.name: nsVrOspfIfMetricValue
nsVrOspfIfMetricValue.description: The metric of using this type of service on this interface. The default value of the TOS 0 Metric is 10^8 / ifSpeed.

nsVrOspfIfMetricStatus.name: nsVrOspfIfMetricStatus
nsVrOspfIfMetricStatus.description: This variable displays the status of the en- try. Setting it to 'invalid' has the effect of rendering it inoperative. The internal effect (row removal) is implementation dependent.

nsVrOspfIfMetricVRID.name: nsVrOspfIfMetricVRID
nsVrOspfIfMetricVRID.description: Virtual Router ID. VRID range for system created VRs: [1-1024] and for user created VRs: [1025-2048]

nsVrOspfVirtIfTable.name: nsVrOspfVirtIfTable
nsVrOspfVirtIfTable.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.4 Virtual link parameters
nsVrOspfVirtIfTable.description: Information about this router's virtual inter- faces.

nsVrOspfVirtIfEntry.name: nsVrOspfVirtIfEntry
nsVrOspfVirtIfEntry.description: Information about a single Virtual Interface.

nsVrOspfVirtIfAreaId.name: nsVrOspfVirtIfAreaId
nsVrOspfVirtIfAreaId.description: The Transit Area that the Virtual Link traverses. By definition, this is not 0.0.0.0

nsVrOspfVirtIfNeighbor.name: nsVrOspfVirtIfNeighbor
nsVrOspfVirtIfNeighbor.description: The Router ID of the Virtual Neighbor.

nsVrOspfVirtIfTransitDelay.name: nsVrOspfVirtIfTransitDelay
nsVrOspfVirtIfTransitDelay.description: The estimated number of seconds it takes to transmit a link- state update packet over this interface.

nsVrOspfVirtIfRetransInterval.name: nsVrOspfVirtIfRetransInterval
nsVrOspfVirtIfRetransInterval.description: The number of seconds between link-state ad- vertisement retransmissions, for adjacencies belonging to this interface. This value is also used when retransmitting database descrip- tion and link-state request packets. This value should be well over the expected round- trip time.

nsVrOspfVirtIfHelloInterval.name: nsVrOspfVirtIfHelloInterval
nsVrOspfVirtIfHelloInterval.description: The length of time, in seconds, between the Hello packets that the router sends on the in- terface. This value must be the same for the virtual neighbor.

nsVrOspfVirtIfRtrDeadInterval.name: nsVrOspfVirtIfRtrDeadInterval
nsVrOspfVirtIfRtrDeadInterval.description: The number of seconds that a router's Hello packets have not been seen before it's neigh- bors declare the router down. This should be some multiple of the Hello interval. This value must be the same for the virtual neigh- bor.

nsVrOspfVirtIfEvents.name: nsVrOspfVirtIfEvents
nsVrOspfVirtIfEvents.description: The number of state changes or error events on this Virtual Link

nsVrOspfVirtIfAuthKey.name: nsVrOspfVirtIfAuthKey
nsVrOspfVirtIfAuthKey.reference: OSPF Version 2, Section 9 The Interface Data Structure
nsVrOspfVirtIfAuthKey.description: If Authentication Type is simplePassword, the device will left adjust and zero fill to 8 oc- tets. Note that unauthenticated interfaces need no authentication key, and simple password authen- tication cannot use a key of more than 8 oc- tets. Larger keys are useful only with authen- tication mechanisms not specified in this docu- ment. When read, nsVrOspfVifAuthKey always returns a string of length zero.

nsVrOspfVirtIfStatus.name: nsVrOspfVirtIfStatus
nsVrOspfVirtIfStatus.description: This variable displays the status of the en- try. Setting it to 'invalid' has the effect of rendering it inoperative. The internal effect (row removal) is implementation dependent.

nsVrOspfVirtIfAuthType.name: nsVrOspfVirtIfAuthType
nsVrOspfVirtIfAuthType.description: The authentication type specified for a virtu- al interface. Additional authentication types may be assigned locally.

nsVrOspfVirtIfVRID.name: nsVrOspfVirtIfVRID
nsVrOspfVirtIfVRID.description: Virtual Router ID. VRID range for system created VRs: [1-1024] and for user created VRs: [1025-2048]

nsVrOspfNbrTable.name: nsVrOspfNbrTable
nsVrOspfNbrTable.reference: OSPF Version 2, Section 10 The Neighbor Data Structure
nsVrOspfNbrTable.description: A table of non-virtual neighbor information.

nsVrOspfNbrEntry.name: nsVrOspfNbrEntry
nsVrOspfNbrEntry.reference: OSPF Version 2, Section 10 The Neighbor Data Structure
nsVrOspfNbrEntry.description: The information regarding a single neighbor.

nsVrOspfNbrIpAddr.name: nsVrOspfNbrIpAddr
nsVrOspfNbrIpAddr.description: The IP address this neighbor is using in its IP Source Address. Note that, on addressless links, this will not be 0.0.0.0, but the ad- dress of another of the neighbor's interfaces.

nsVrOspfNbrAddressLessIndex.name: nsVrOspfNbrAddressLessIndex
nsVrOspfNbrAddressLessIndex.description: On an interface having an IP Address, zero. On addressless interfaces, the corresponding value of ifIndex in the Internet Standard MIB. On row creation, this can be derived from the instance.

nsVrOspfNbrRtrId.name: nsVrOspfNbrRtrId
nsVrOspfNbrRtrId.description: A 32-bit integer (represented as a type IpAd- dress) uniquely identifying the neighboring router in the Autonomous System.

nsVrOspfNbrOptions.name: nsVrOspfNbrOptions
nsVrOspfNbrOptions.description: A Bit Mask corresponding to the neighbor's op- tions field. Bit 0, if set, indicates that the system will operate on Type of Service metrics other than TOS 0. If zero, the neighbor will ignore all metrics except the TOS 0 metric. Bit 1, if set, indicates that the associated area accepts and operates on external informa- tion; if zero, it is a stub area. Bit 2, if set, indicates that the system is ca- pable of routing IP Multicast datagrams; i.e., that it implements the Multicast Extensions to OSPF. Bit 3, if set, indicates that the associated area is an NSSA. These areas are capable of carrying type 7 external advertisements, which are translated into type 5 external advertise- ments at NSSA borders.

nsVrOspfNbrPriority.name: nsVrOspfNbrPriority
nsVrOspfNbrPriority.description: The priority of this neighbor in the designat- ed router election algorithm. The value 0 sig- nifies that the neighbor is not eligible to be- come the designated router on this particular network.

nsVrOspfNbrState.name: nsVrOspfNbrState
nsVrOspfNbrState.description: The State of the relationship with this Neigh- bor.

nsVrOspfNbrEvents.name: nsVrOspfNbrEvents
nsVrOspfNbrEvents.description: The number of times this neighbor relationship has changed state, or an error has occurred.

nsVrOspfNbrLsRetransQLen.name: nsVrOspfNbrLsRetransQLen
nsVrOspfNbrLsRetransQLen.description: The current length of the retransmission queue.

nsVrOspfNbmaNbrStatus.name: nsVrOspfNbmaNbrStatus
nsVrOspfNbmaNbrStatus.description: This variable displays the status of the en- try. Setting it to 'invalid' has the effect of rendering it inoperative. The internal effect (row removal) is implementation dependent.

nsVrOspfNbmaNbrPermanence.name: nsVrOspfNbmaNbrPermanence
nsVrOspfNbmaNbrPermanence.description: This variable displays the status of the en- try. 'dynamic' and 'permanent' refer to how the neighbor became known.

nsVrOspfNbrHelloSuppressed.name: nsVrOspfNbrHelloSuppressed
nsVrOspfNbrHelloSuppressed.description: Indicates whether Hellos are being suppressed to the neighbor

nsVrOspfNbrVRID.name: nsVrOspfNbrVRID
nsVrOspfNbrVRID.description: Virtual Router ID. VRID range for system created VRs: [1-1024] and for user created VRs: [1025-2048]

nsVrOspfVirtNbrTable.name: nsVrOspfVirtNbrTable
nsVrOspfVirtNbrTable.description: A table of virtual neighbor information.

nsVrOspfVirtNbrRtrId.name: nsVrOspfVirtNbrRtrId
nsVrOspfVirtNbrRtrId.description: A 32-bit integer uniquely identifying the neighboring router in the Autonomous System.

nsVrOspfVirtNbrIpAddr.name: nsVrOspfVirtNbrIpAddr
nsVrOspfVirtNbrIpAddr.description: The IP address this Virtual Neighbor is us- ing.

nsVrOspfVirtNbrOptions.name: nsVrOspfVirtNbrOptions
nsVrOspfVirtNbrOptions.description: A Bit Mask corresponding to the neighbor's op- tions field. Bit 1, if set, indicates that the system will operate on Type of Service metrics other than TOS 0. If zero, the neighbor will ignore all metrics except the TOS 0 metric. Bit 2, if set, indicates that the system is Network Multicast capable; ie, that it imple- ments OSPF Multicast Routing.

nsVrOspfVirtNbrState.name: nsVrOspfVirtNbrState
nsVrOspfVirtNbrState.description: The state of the Virtual Neighbor Relation- ship.

nsVrOspfVirtNbrEvents.name: nsVrOspfVirtNbrEvents
nsVrOspfVirtNbrEvents.description: The number of times this virtual link has changed its state, or an error has occurred.

nsVrOspfVirtNbrLsRetransQLen.name: nsVrOspfVirtNbrLsRetransQLen
nsVrOspfVirtNbrLsRetransQLen.description: The current length of the retransmission queue.

nsVrOspfVirtNbrHelloSuppressed.name: nsVrOspfVirtNbrHelloSuppressed
nsVrOspfVirtNbrHelloSuppressed.description: Indicates whether Hellos are being suppressed to the neighbor

nsVrOspfVirtNbrVRID.name: nsVrOspfVirtNbrVRID
nsVrOspfVirtNbrVRID.description: Virtual Router ID. VRID range for system created VRs: [1-1024] and for user created VRs: [1025-2048]

nsVrOspfExtLsdbTable.name: nsVrOspfExtLsdbTable
nsVrOspfExtLsdbTable.reference: OSPF Version 2, Section 12 Link State Adver- tisements
nsVrOspfExtLsdbTable.description: The OSPF Process's Links State Database.

nsVrOspfExtLsdbType.name: nsVrOspfExtLsdbType
nsVrOspfExtLsdbType.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix A.4.1 The Link State Advertisement header
nsVrOspfExtLsdbType.description: The type of the link state advertisement. Each link state type has a separate advertise- ment format.

nsVrOspfExtLsdbLsid.name: nsVrOspfExtLsdbLsid
nsVrOspfExtLsdbLsid.reference: OSPF Version 2, Section 12.1.4 Link State ID
nsVrOspfExtLsdbLsid.description: The Link State ID is an LS Type Specific field containing either a Router ID or an IP Address; it identifies the piece of the routing domain that is being described by the advertisement.

nsVrOspfExtLsdbRouterId.name: nsVrOspfExtLsdbRouterId
nsVrOspfExtLsdbRouterId.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.1 Global parameters
nsVrOspfExtLsdbRouterId.description: The 32 bit number that uniquely identifies the originating router in the Autonomous System.

nsVrOspfExtLsdbSequence.name: nsVrOspfExtLsdbSequence
nsVrOspfExtLsdbSequence.reference: OSPF Version 2, Section 12.1.6 LS sequence number
nsVrOspfExtLsdbSequence.description: The sequence number field is a signed 32-bit integer. It is used to detect old and dupli- cate link state advertisements. The space of sequence numbers is linearly ordered. The larger the sequence number the more recent the advertisement.

nsVrOspfExtLsdbAge.name: nsVrOspfExtLsdbAge
nsVrOspfExtLsdbAge.description: This field is the age of the link state adver- tisement in seconds.

nsVrOspfExtLsdbChecksum.name: nsVrOspfExtLsdbChecksum
nsVrOspfExtLsdbChecksum.description: This field is the checksum of the complete contents of the advertisement, excepting the age field. The age field is excepted so that an advertisement's age can be incremented without updating the checksum. The checksum used is the same that is used for ISO connec- tionless datagrams; it is commonly referred to as the Fletcher checksum.

nsVrOspfExtLsdbAdvertisement.name: nsVrOspfExtLsdbAdvertisement
nsVrOspfExtLsdbAdvertisement.reference: OSPF Version 2, Section 12 Link State Adver- tisements
nsVrOspfExtLsdbAdvertisement.description: The entire Link State Advertisement, including its header.

nsVrOspfExtLsdbVRID.name: nsVrOspfExtLsdbVRID
nsVrOspfExtLsdbVRID.description: Virtual Router ID. VRID range for system created VRs: [1-1024] and for user created VRs: [1025-2048]

nsVrOspfAreaAggregateTable.name: nsVrOspfAreaAggregateTable
nsVrOspfAreaAggregateTable.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.2 Area parameters
nsVrOspfAreaAggregateTable.description: A range of IP addresses specified by an IP address/IP network mask pair. For example, class B address range of X.X.X.X with a network mask of 255.255.0.0 includes all IP addresses from X.X.0.0 to X.X.255.255. Note that if ranges are configured such that one range sub- sumes another range (e.g., 10.0.0.0 mask 255.0.0.0 and 10.1.0.0 mask 255.255.0.0), the most specific match is the preferred one.

nsVrOspfAreaAggregateEntry.name: nsVrOspfAreaAggregateEntry
nsVrOspfAreaAggregateEntry.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.2 Area parameters
nsVrOspfAreaAggregateEntry.description: A range of IP addresses specified by an IP address/IP network mask pair. For example, class B address range of X.X.X.X with a network mask of 255.255.0.0 includes all IP addresses from X.X.0.0 to X.X.255.255. Note that if ranges are range configured such that one range subsumes another range (e.g., 10.0.0.0 mask 255.0.0.0 and 10.1.0.0 mask 255.255.0.0), the most specific match is the preferred one.

nsVrOspfAreaAggregateAreaID.name: nsVrOspfAreaAggregateAreaID
nsVrOspfAreaAggregateAreaID.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.2 Area parameters
nsVrOspfAreaAggregateAreaID.description: The Area the Address Aggregate is to be found within.

nsVrOspfAreaAggregateLsdbType.name: nsVrOspfAreaAggregateLsdbType
nsVrOspfAreaAggregateLsdbType.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix A.4.1 The Link State Advertisement header
nsVrOspfAreaAggregateLsdbType.description: The type of the Address Aggregate. This field specifies the Lsdb type that this Address Ag- gregate applies to.

nsVrOspfAreaAggregateNet.name: nsVrOspfAreaAggregateNet
nsVrOspfAreaAggregateNet.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.2 Area parameters
nsVrOspfAreaAggregateNet.description: The IP Address of the Net or Subnet indicated by the range.

nsVrOspfAreaAggregateMask.name: nsVrOspfAreaAggregateMask
nsVrOspfAreaAggregateMask.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.2 Area parameters
nsVrOspfAreaAggregateMask.description: The Subnet Mask that pertains to the Net or Subnet.

nsVrOspfAreaAggregateStatus.name: nsVrOspfAreaAggregateStatus
nsVrOspfAreaAggregateStatus.description: This variable displays the status of the en- try. Setting it to 'invalid' has the effect of rendering it inoperative. The internal effect (row removal) is implementation dependent.

nsVrOspfAreaAggregateEffect.name: nsVrOspfAreaAggregateEffect
nsVrOspfAreaAggregateEffect.description: Subnets subsumed by ranges either trigger the advertisement of the indicated aggregate (ad- vertiseMatching), or result in the subnet's not being advertised at all outside the area.

nsVrOspfAreaAggregateVRID.name: nsVrOspfAreaAggregateVRID
nsVrOspfAreaAggregateVRID.description: Virtual Router ID. VRID range for system created VRs: [1-1024] and for user created VRs: [1025-2048]
